channel.title: News
channel.description: NPR news, audio, and podcasts. Coverage of breaking stories, national and world news, politics, business, science, technology, and extended coverage of major national and world events.
channel.copyright: Copyright 2012 NPR - For Personal Use Only

item.title: Russian Agency Says It Foiled Potential Attack On Sochi, 2014 Olympics Host City
item.description: A Russian anti-terrorism agency says that its secret service agents have thwarted a planned attack on Sochi, the city slated to host the 2014 Winter Olympics. Russia's FSB security service says it found 10 caches of weapons.
item.content:encoded:
A Russian anti-terrorism agency says that its secret service agents have thwarted a planned attack on Sochi, the city slated to host the 2014 Winter Olympics. Russia's FSB security service says it found 10 caches of weapons.

» E-Mail This     » Add to Del.icio.us

item.title: Survey: Americans Overwhelmingly Support Defense Cuts
item.description: After receiving a briefing on the federal budget, Republicans and Democrats took bold decisions when it came to defense spending. And they proposed cuts that go far beyond what both parties in Congress have proposed.
item.content:encoded:
After receiving a briefing on the federal budget, Republicans and Democrats took bold decisions when it came to defense spending. And they proposed cuts that go far beyond what both parties in Congress have proposed.

item.title: Reaction To Obama's Same-Sex Marriage Suppport: From Sublime To Silly
item.description: The response to the president naturally cut across the ideological spectrum. It also ranged from the sublime to the ridiculous.
item.content:encoded:
The response to the president naturally cut across the ideological spectrum. It also ranged from the sublime to the ridiculous.

item.title: Why It Matters That California Teens Eat Less Than Their Peers
item.description: California teens eat about 158 calories less a day than their peers in other states, a new study says. But even that tiny amount of fewer calories per kid can help them maintain healthy weights over time, experts say.
item.content:encoded:
California teens eat about 158 calories less a day than their peers in other states, a new study says. But even that tiny amount of fewer calories per kid can help them maintain healthy weights over time, experts say.

item.title: Obama Heads To Hollywood; Conservative Group Mocks 'Celebrity President'
item.description: On Thursday, some of Hollywood's top stars and deepest pockets will congregate at the Studio City, Calif., home of actor George Clooney to mingle with President Obama and raise money for his re-election campaign. At least one conservative group is deriding Obama as a "celebrity president."
item.content:encoded:
On Thursday, some of Hollywood's top stars and deepest pockets will congregate at the Studio City, Calif., home of actor George Clooney to mingle with President Obama and raise money for his re-election campaign. At least one conservative group is deriding Obama as a "celebrity president."

» E-Mail This     » Add to Del.icio.us

item.title: And Now For The Weather, Let's Go To Prince Charles
item.description: In Scotland, viewers of a nightly BBC news program got a surprise when Prince Charles stood in front of a weather map to tell them about all the rain and cold they'd soon experience. "We're under the influence of low pressure," he said.
item.content:encoded:
In Scotland, viewers of a nightly BBC news program got a surprise when Prince Charles stood in front of a weather map to tell them about all the rain and cold they'd soon experience. "We're under the influence of low pressure," he said.

» E-Mail This     » Add to Del.icio.us

item.title: Romney: 'Back In High School, I Did Some Dumb Things'
item.description: Mitt Romney on Thursday apologized for pranks he played in high school that "might have gone too far," after The Washington Post reported on his alleged participation in the bullying of a student often teased for his "presumed homosexuality." Romney said he didn't remember the particular incident.
item.content:encoded:
Mitt Romney on Thursday apologized for pranks he played in high school that "might have gone too far," after The Washington Post reported on his alleged participation in the bullying of a student often teased for his "presumed homosexuality." Romney said he didn't remember the particular incident.

item.title: Justice Department Sues Ariz. Sheriff Arpaio
item.description: The federal government is accusing the Maricopa County sheriff of violating the civil rights of Latinos in his district.
item.content:encoded:
The federal government is accusing the Maricopa County sheriff of violating the civil rights of Latinos in his district.

item.title: Will Same-Sex Marriage Rile Faith Leaders?
item.description: President Obama says he supports same-sex marriage, becoming the first sitting U.S. president to come out in favor of the issue. Host Michel Martin looks at what it means for the November elections, and for an issue that many Americans view in religious or moral terms. Martin speaks with two religion reporters: Sarah Posner of Religion Dispatches and David Brody of the Christian Broadcasting Network.
item.content:encoded:
President Obama says he supports same-sex marriage, becoming the first sitting U.S. president to come out in favor of the issue. Host Michel Martin looks at what it means for the November elections, and for an issue that many Americans view in religious or moral terms. Martin speaks with two religion reporters: Sarah Posner of Religion Dispatches and David Brody of the Christian Broadcasting Network.

» E-Mail This     » Add to Del.icio.us

item.title: Why Mayor Barrett Wants To Defeat His Governor
item.description: Milwaukee Mayor Tom Barrett won the Democratic primary earlier this week, earning the chance to challenge Wisconsin Governor Scott Walker at the polls. Barrett lost a race for the governor's seat to Walker in 2010. Host Michel Martin speaks with Barrett about whether the outrage over Walker's cuts to collective bargaining rights will be enough for him to win this rematch.
item.content:encoded:
Milwaukee Mayor Tom Barrett won the Democratic primary earlier this week, earning the chance to challenge Wisconsin Governor Scott Walker at the polls. Barrett lost a race for the governor's seat to Walker in 2010. Host Michel Martin speaks with Barrett about whether the outrage over Walker's cuts to collective bargaining rights will be enough for him to win this rematch.

item.title: Mars Rover Opportunity Emerges From Winter Doldrums, Gets Back On Move
item.description: With the darkest days of the Martian winter now over, NASA took its Opportunity Mars Rover for a drive this week. The rover had been stationary while its solar panels lacked enough sunlight to power its batteries.
item.content:encoded:
With the darkest days of the Martian winter now over, NASA took its Opportunity Mars Rover for a drive this week. The rover had been stationary while its solar panels lacked enough sunlight to power its batteries.

item.title: Recalculating The Health Bill In McAllen, Texas
item.description: The government has identified hundreds of hospitals where Medicare patients are incurring especially high or low bills. Hospitals around McAllen, it turns out, aren't as terrible as they were made out to be, according to Medicare's calculations of how much it spent for the average patient from three days before admission to a month after discharge.
item.content:encoded:
The government has identified hundreds of hospitals where Medicare patients are incurring especially high or low bills. Hospitals around McAllen, it turns out, aren't as terrible as they were made out to be, according to Medicare's calculations of how much it spent for the average patient from three days before admission to a month after discharge.

item.title: Horse Racing: America's Most Dangerous Game?
item.description: Two reporters for The New York Times detail their monthslong investigation of America's racetracks. Since 2009, more than 6,600 horses have broken down or showed signs of injury at U.S. racetracks, a rate much higher than in other countries.
item.content:encoded:
Two reporters for The New York Times detail their monthslong investigation of America's racetracks. Since 2009, more than 6,600 horses have broken down or showed signs of injury at U.S. racetracks, a rate much higher than in other countries.

item.title: Putin Cancels Visit To U.S., Meeting With Obama
item.description: Kremlin cites need to put finishing touches on newly re-installed Vladimir Putin's Cabinet.
item.content:encoded:

item.title: The Ideas America Sells To The World
item.description: U.S. exports aren't limited to stuff. We also sell billions of dollars worth of ideas to people around the world.
item.content:encoded:
